title: Ticket #173: Sample Excel and MS Office Jobs
description: It would be nice to have a set of sample that showed how to use Condor to use automated MS Office scripts. At a minimum, there is a clear need for Excel samples, as this one is mentioned more frequently than any of the others.
remarks:
2009-May-01 14:08:25 by burnett:
Methods are outlined here. Once the document is complete, it will be added to the manual.

2009-May-22 12:02:38 by ziliang:
I'm currently using the ForceFullCalculation variable in order to decide whether to do a massive update. There doesn't seem to be a way to set it using cmd argument switches in Excel, so a way to set it within the spreadsheet needs to be determined. Or we could leave it up to the end-user to come up with their own way.

2009-May-28 13:31:48 by burnett:
Please see this page for a very simple GUI based solution.

2009-May-28 15:39:27 by burnett:
A Python example can be found here.

2009-Jun-21 15:49:39 by ziliang:
Found the Registry value that controls the macro settings for security. For Office 2007, the key is in HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\12.0\Excel\Security and is called VBAWarnings. Set it to 1 and it will enable all VBA scripts. Depending on what other versions we intend to support for this, I'll need to get a copy and install it. We'll also need to make sure people can't do something malicious with this, since in theory they could put together a VBA script that screws with the system.

2009-Jun-22 13:15:55 by ziliang:
Key in Office 2003 is located in HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\11.0\Excel\Security and is called Level. Also appears that we need to set it to 1 to disable security.

2009-Jun-29 12:06:50 by tannenba:
Another idea for a different approach altogether: scrap all the VBScript mumbo jumbo ;) and use a gui automater like WinBatch or its freeware alternative AutoIT.

2009-Jun-30 00:30:50 by burnett:
If you're going that route, then just use the VBScript engine included with the Windows Scripting Host. The WSH already supports a great deal of GUI automation capabilities, and it is available on a stock Windows machine.

2009-Jun-30 09:53:39 by ziliang:
Isn't the WSH automation what you were doing originally, except that the settings needed rendered it unusable by anyone else?
